Award.AwardTitle: Collab. Research: Instability analysis of the split-step method on spatially-varying backgrounds, with applications to optical telecommunications and Bose-Einstein condensation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The operator-splitting, or split-step, method (SSM) is widely used to numerically solve time-dependent partial differential equations arising in diverse applications, from hydrodynamics to quantum mechanics. To minimize the computational time, one needs to select the time step as large as possible. On the other hand, the upper bound on the time step is often set by the requirement that the numerical scheme be stable. The von Neumann analysis is used to obtain such upper bounds for model problems where the coefficients are constant. However, solutions of practically interesting equations are typically not constant in space. To justify the use of the von Neumann analysis for such problems, one often approximates non-constant coefficients by constant ones. However, for the SSM, this approach fails. Recently, we proposed an alternative approach to analyze the instability of the SSM when this method is used to simulate a solution close to the soliton (i.e., a bell-shaped solution) of the nonlinear Schroedinger equation. In this project, we will extend that analysis to more practically relevant settings that involve two applications: fiber optical telecommunications and Bose?Einstein condensates. This will provide an understanding of the development of the numerical instability in problems with essentially non-constant coefficients. We will then use this information to propose modifications of the SSM with relaxed stability requirements. Clearly, this will reduce the computational time.

This project will develop a systematic approach to studying a fundamental property "stability" of a widely used numerical method, the SSM. A numerical method must be stable in order to accurately model the physical process of interest. The current approach to the stability analysis consists in approximating the simulated processes by some constant values. We will not use this approximation, as we have demonstrated that it leads to incorrect predictions regarding the performance of the SSM. Our alternative approach will rely on a combination of techniques from numerical analysis and the theory of linear differential equations. It will provide an understanding of the performance limitations of the SSM. This, in turn, will allow us to propose more efficient and reliable modifications of this numerical method. The applications considered in this project will directly impact the modeling of fiber-optic communication systems and low-temperature atomic condensates. However, our approach will affect other applications of the SSM, which include environmental modeling, hydrology, heat conduction, and reacting flows. Moreover, the approach can be extended to related numerical methods, which are used in other applications such as the modeling of the interaction among molecules and chemical species through reactions and random motion (diffusion).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The operator-splitting, or split-step, method (SSM) is widely used to numerically solve time-dependent partial differential equations (PDEs) arising in diverse physical applications. To minimize the computational time, one needs to select the time step as large as accuracy considerations allow. However, in many situations, the upper bound on the time step is set not by accuracy, but by the requirement that the numerical scheme be stable.

            The standard “tool” – von Neumann analysis – used to find the stability threshold for the time step, requires that the coefficients of the simulated equation be constant. However, most practically interesting equations have spatially varying coefficients. The PI had recently proposed an alternative approach to the von Neumann analysis for one version (Fourier) of the SSM for certain pulse-like solutions of the nonlinear Schroedinger equation (NLS). In this project, we extended that work as follows.

            First, we showed that for (pseudo)random solutions of the NLS, numerical instability of the Fourier SSM develops much slower than for solutions with regular shape. This finding allows one to use time steps that exceed the stability threshold by a factor of approximately two, and hence reduce the computational time proportionally, in fiber-optical communications, where the signal often has random shape.

            Second, we proposed two alternative methods for the Fourier SSM. One of those methods has a much higher stability threshold than the Fourier SSM. Consequently, its step size is limited only by the accuracy requirement, not by stability. With this new method, we were able to reduce the computational time by a factor of 3 to 4 for one-dimensional problems and by a factor of 6 to 8 for two-dimensional ones.

            Third, we considered a different version of the SSM: finite-difference instead of Fourier, and established mechanisms by which numerical instability may develop for it. These mechanisms are different from the mechanism of the numerical instability for the Fourier SSM. The understanding of these mechanisms is important because of the following:

     (i) It can help one to detect if one’s numerical results are “contaminated” by a numerical instability, is may sometimes appear as a “true”, i.e. non-numerical, effect.

     (ii) It allows one to tell when the numerical instability can be suppressed by simple means (e.g., applying absorbing boundary conditions), and when it cannot be.

            Fourth, we considered other evolution equations (a fractional NLS and a nonlinear Dirac equation), and found their stability thresholds when they are simulated by the Fourier SSM. Moreover, for the nonlinear Dirac equation, we found that the Fourier SSM can become unconditionally unstable (i.e., unstable for any time step, no matter how small). To our knowledge, unconditional instability of the Fourier SSM has never been reported before. Our finding is important, as it should alert users of this well-tested method of the possibility of its results being unreliable even for very small time steps.

            Fifth, for yet another evolution PDE, we considered schemes based on the widely used Method of characteristics and some widely used numerical solvers for ordinary differential equations (ODEs). We obtained and analytically explained two unexpected results:

     (i) The fact that a numerical solver can perform well for a class of ODEs does not mean that it can perform well for a related class of PDEs within the Method of characteristics framework.

     (ii)  We showed that a widely accepted statement that a numerical instability of a scheme with periodic boundary conditions always implies an instability of that scheme with any other boundary conditions, is incorrect. We found a reason for this behavior, as well as identified general features of a scheme where it may or may not occur.

 

             In addition to the above findings in the principal area of this research, we also obtained a number of results in other areas of applied mathematics. The broader impact of the project includes:

            First, we found that multiplicative noise in some range of parameters can significantly increase the probability of extreme events in nonlinear Schroedinger-type equations. This can have applications in statistical studies of nonlinear waves, e.g., weak turbulence in hydrodynamics.

            Second, by using one of the new numerical methods, that we proposed as an alternative to the Fourier SSM, in an astrophysical application, we found a possible cause of strong bursts of pulsar radiation.

            Third, we found a reason for a recent controversy between analytical and numerical predictions about the stability of the so-called soliton (a stationary pulse) of nonlinear Dirac equations.

 

            The project resulted in 5 published papers (so far), 1 paper under review (as a minor revision), 2 submitted manuscripts, 3 manuscripts in preparation (with expected completion within a year), 4 conference presentations, 1 invited presentation, and 1 defended M.S. thesis.

            The project supported training and professional development of: 1 postdoctoral researcher (for 1 year), 1 graduate student (for 1 year), and 1 undergraduate student (for 2 summer months).
